tag bracket.bubble:
In markup languages (like HTML and others), the < (less-than) and > (greater-than) symbols are syntax used to create tags.

Tags usually come in pairs, an opening <tag> followed by some content and then a closing </tag> (differentiated by the forward slash).

A pair of tags are referred to as an element. Different markup languages have their own list of elements, some even let you create your own!

comment.bubble:
Most coding languages allow you to leave comments in your code. In HTML you can create a comment by starting it with <!-- and ending with -->. Code are instructions, it's how you tell the browser what you want it to display, but browsers ignore comments. Comments are for people, not machines.

Coders use them for all sorts of reasons, most often for leaving notes explaining how the code works (future you will thank you for that). It's also a great way to credit any code snippets you've copy+pasted from somewhere else. They can also be used to "comment out" code, so that the browser ignores it temporarily without having to remove it.

The shortcut key CTRL+/ (control forward-slash), or CMD+/ (command forward-slash) on Mac, can be used to comment out lines of code.

a.bubble: The <a> tag (or "anchor element"), with its href attribute, can be used to create hyperlinks to other web pages, files, email addresses, another location in the same page or anything else a URL can point to.
a.example: further down back to top home page home page call Tommy Tutone say hello! download

audio.example:
<!-- simple example -->
<audio src="audios/katy.mp3" controls></audio>

<!-- specifying different types -->
<!-- the browser will choose the version it can support -->
<audio controls>
  <source src="audios/katy.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  <source src="audios/katy.ogg" type="audio/ogg">
</audio>

br.example:
CLOUD PIECE
by Yoko Ono

Imagine the clouds dripping.
Dig a hole in your garden to
put them in.

1963 spring

datalist.bubble: Used in combintion with the <input> and <option> elements, the <datalist> element is used to create a text field with auto-suggestions (based on it's <option> elements) that drop down as the user types into it.
datalist.example:
<!-- text field with auto-suggestions -->
<input list="ice-cream-flavors" placeholder="ice-cream flavor">
<datalist id="ice-cream-flavors">
  <option value="Chocolate"></option>
  <option value="Coconut"></option>
  <option value="Mint"></option>
  <option value="Strawberry"></option>
  <option value="Vanilla"></option>
</datalist>

h1.bubble: The <h1> element is used to create a heading, like the title of a section or the by-line of a news article. The content in headings appear larger than the content of most other elements. Of the 6 levels, this <h1> heading is the largest

h2.bubble: The <h2> element is used to create a heading, like the title of a section or the by-line of a news article. The content in headings appear larger than the content of most other elements. Of the 6 levels, this <h2> heading is the second largest

h3.bubble: The <h3> element is used to create a heading, like the title of a section or the by-line of a news article. The content in headings appear larger than the content of most other elements. Of the 6 levels, this <h3> heading is the third largest

h4.bubble: The <h4> element is used to create a heading, like the title of a section or the by-line of a news article. The content in headings appear larger than the content of most other elements. Of the 6 levels, this <h4> heading is the fourth largest

h5.bubble: The <h5> element is used to create a heading, like the title of a section or the by-line of a news article. The content in headings appear larger than the content of most other elements. Of the 6 levels, this <h5> heading is the fifth largest

h6.bubble: The <h6> element is used to create a heading, like the title of a section or the by-line of a article. The content in headings appear larger than the content of most other elements. Of the 6 levels, this <h6> heading is the smallest

img.bubble: The <img> element is used to embed an image. As a "singleton" or "void element" it does not have a closing tag. It does, however, require at least one html attribute, the src attribute: <img src="path/to/file.jpg">

input.bubble: The HTML <input> element is used to create interactive controls and common GUI (graphical user interface) elements often used in forms. A wide variety of types are available.
input.example:
<!-- a text field -->
<input type="text" placeholder="your username">
<!-- a password field -->
<input type="password" placeholder="secret password">
<!-- color selector -->
<input type="color">
<!-- slider -->
<input type="range">
<!-- a radio button -->
<input type="radio">
<!-- a check box -->
<input type="checkbox" checked="true">
<!-- click the link at the top or bottom of this reference for more examples -->

link.bubble: The <link> element is most commonly used to import a CSS file (most commonly referred to as a "stylesheet") into the HTML page, so that the rules defined in the stylesheet can be applied to any of the elements on this page. The link can also be used to preload resources (like fonts) and to set your projects icons (for mobile apps and browser tabs).
link.example:
<!-- importing a CSS stylesheet -->
<link href="path/to/styles.css" rel="stylesheet">
<!-- adding a favicon (appears in browser tab) to a page -->
<link rel="icon" href="favicon.ico">
<!-- adding icon for mobile apps -->
<link rel="apple-touch-icon" href="icon.png">
<!-- preloading fonts -->
<link rel="preload" href="myFont.woff2" as="font" type="font/woff2" crossorigin="anonymous">
<!-- to learn more about "preloading" assets see: -->
<!-- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Link_types/preload -->

option.bubble: As the name implies, the <option> element is used to define a selectable item in a <select> (dropdown menu) or <datalist> (auto-suggestion search field) element.
option.example:
<!-- text field with auto-suggestions -->
<input list="ice-cream-flavors" placeholder="ice-cream flavor">
<datalist id="ice-cream-flavors">
  <option value="Chocolate"></option>
  <option value="Coconut"></option>
  <option value="Mint"></option>
  <option value="Strawberry"></option>
  <option value="Vanilla"></option>
</datalist>

<!-- a drop-down list -->
<select id="pet-select">
  <option value="">--Please choose a pet--</option>
  <option value="dog">Dog</option>
  <option value="cat">Cat</option>
  <option value="hamster">Hamster</option>
  <option value="parrot">Parrot</option>
  <option value="spider">Spider</option>
  <option value="goldfish">Goldfish</option>
</select>

ol.example:

  3. Diagonal l. to r.

and their combinations.

Four basic kinds of straight lines:
  • Vertical

li.example:
Four basic kinds of straight lines:
  1. Vertical
  2. Horizontal
  3. Diagonal l. to r.
  4. Diagonal r. to l.
and their combinations.

pre.bubble: In HTML, line breaks and indentation in your code are not rendered in the browser. The <pre> tag, or "preformatted text" element, is an exception to this rule. Any content in between opening and closing <pre> tags will be rendered exactly as it appears in the HTML code (tabs, line breaks and all).

select.bubble: Used in combintion with the <option> element, the <select> element is used to create a dropdown menu.
select.example:
<!-- a drop-down list -->
<select id="pet-select">
  <option value="">--Please choose a pet--</option>
  <option value="dog">Dog</option>
  <option value="cat">Cat</option>
  <option value="hamster">Hamster</option>
  <option value="parrot">Parrot</option>
  <option value="spider">Spider</option>
  <option value="goldfish">Goldfish</option>
</select>

source.bubble: The <source> element specifies multiple media resources for it's parent element, for example <picture>, <video> and <audio>. It is commonly used to offer the same media content in multiple file formats in order to provide compatibility with a broad range of browsers given their differing support for image file formats and media file formats.
source.example:
<video controls>
  <source src="videos/screen-saver.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  <source src="videos/screen-saver.webm" type="video/webm">
  <source src="videos/screen-saver.ogv" type="video/ogg">
</video>

<audio controls>
  <source src="audios/katy.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  <source src="audios/katy.ogg" type="audio/ogg">
</audio>

video.example:
<!-- video with controls present -->
<video src="videos/screen-saver.mp4" controls>

<!-- specifying different types -->
<!-- the browser will choose the version it can support -->
<video controls>
  <source src="videos/screen-saver.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  <source src="videos/screen-saver.webm" type="video/webm">
  <source src="videos/screen-saver.ogv" type="video/ogg">
</video>

alt.bubble: The alt attribute provides alternative information for an image if a user for some reason cannot view it (because of slow connection or an error in the src attribute). If the user is using a screen reader (because they are visually impaired for example) the alt attribute is also used to provide a caption to read aloud. For these reasons it also helps improve your page's SEO.

href.bubble: The href attribute is used to create a hyperlink to another reference (resource, file, page, etc), by assigning a URL as it's value. This can be an absolute/relative URL or any other URL scheme supported by browsers. Check out more examples in the <a> reference page.
href.example: home page about us more info below

src.bubble: The src attribute is used to embed content (other assets or even other web pages), by assigning a URL to another file's location as it's value.

target.bubble: Specifies where to open the linked document (in the case of an <a> element) or where to display the response received (in the case of a <form>element). Setting it's value to target="_blank" for example will open the linked page on a new tab.
target.example: home page

type.bubble: The type attribute is used to change the default type of elements like <input> and <source> which can have different control, media or other types.
type.exmaple:
<!-- different "types" of inputs -->
<input type="text" placeholder="your username">
<!-- slider -->
<input type="range">
<!-- color selector -->
<input type="color">

<!-- different "types" of videos -->
<video controls>
  <source src="videos/screen-saver.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  <source src="videos/screen-saver.webm" type="video/webm">
  <source src="videos/screen-saver.ogv" type="video/ogg">
</video>
